description.narrative: (a) To strengthen the performance of key budget organizations in budget formulation, budget execution, and public procurement; (b) To establish the foundations for fiscally sustainable payroll management and effective human resource management in the core civil service; and (c) To create conditions for further automation of government work processes and for development of e-government applications.

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Ref. PAD III.F. | Description :Covenants applicable to project implementation:Other conditions in LegalAgreements and Financial Covenants: The Project Coordinator w i l lsubmit Annual Work Plans approved by the Inter-Govern |Frequency :Yearly

title.narrative: Improved quality of budget formulation and execution in the budget organizations that would participate in the proposed project

baseline.value: PEFA assessment 2009 indicators: # PI-1: score: C (actual expenditure deviated from budget by more than 15% in one of the lastthree years);# PI-12 (iii, iv): Multi-year perspective in fiscal planning, expenditure policy & budgeting # score: C PI-12 (iii)score: C; PI-12 (iv) score: D;# Only 3/7 quality indicators of budget submissions met by all 5 beneficiary BOs; no BO meets 3quality indicators for budget execution

target.value: PEFA PI-1 score B; PEFA PI-12 (iii), (iv) score B;At least 4/5 beneficiary organizations meet at least 5/7 intermediate outcomeindicators

actual.value: PEFA 2013PI-01 = BPI-12 = C+PI-12(iii) = CPI-12 (iv) = DDisaggregated data provided separatelyQuality indicators partiallymet

title.narrative: Improved budget execution rates by beneficiary budget organizations (BOs)

baseline.value: (a) Deviation from original approved budget expenditure by beneficiary BOs does not exceed 10 percent (in aggregate and by BO) forthe year. (3/5=NO)(b) Variance in expenditure composition exceeds overall deviation in primary expenditure by no more than 5percentage points for the year. (5=NO)(c) Targets (expenditure and milestones) for at least 70 percent of projects in approvedbudgets are achieved. (5= NO)

target.value: All beneficiary BOs meet the interim outcome indicators for budget execution

actual.value: a. Partially met. Health met, Education and Agriculture did not.b. Partially met. Agriculture and Health met. Education didnot.c. Partially met. Education met, others did not.

title.narrative: Increased bidder participation in public procurement tenders and cost savings achieved through Quick Gains actions and e-procurement modules

baseline.value: 8,270 bidders participated in procurement tenders in 2008 (1.7 bidders per contract);No electronic procurement transactions;QGstudy reports significant price disparities within procurement categories in the same year (2008):# Civil works/ roads: up to 90%;# Maintenance: 39%# Security: 41%; # Buildings rental 64%; # Food 95%; # Medicines 17-70%; # Office supplies 26%; # Fuel9.3% in a year/ up to 31% in a monthNo electronic procurement transactions QG study reports significant price disparitieswithin procurement categories in the same year (2008):# Civil works/ roads: up to 90%; # Maintenance: 39%# Security: 41%;# Buildings rental 64%; # Food 95%; # Medicines 17-70%; # Office supplies 26%; # Fuel 9.3% in a year/ up to 31% in a month

target.value: Bidder participation increases by 15%.Price disparities in QG procurement categories do not exceed 10% in the same year.Costsavings of at least 5% for each category achieved.

actual.value: Partially met.On January 5th, 2016 the Government announced start of piloting phase of the e-procurement system with six selectedCAs. The actual piloting started on March 15, 2016. On June 11, 2016 the Minister of Ministry of Finance sent a letter to theBank with a request to extend the project closing date. The main justification for the extension was the Government decision tostart using of e-procurement system by central government CAs on September 1, 2016 and by local government CAs on January 1, 2017,and that in order to achieve these, there is a need to introduce into the system changes/amendments of the Law on PublicProcurement adopted in February 2016. Based on this letter and project completion report, the Bank on June 30 has approvedextension of closing date of PSMP untill December 31, 2016. The Central Procurement Agency (CPA) confirmed that during 2015through centralized procurement procedures conducted procurement in 11 categories and achieved to complete

title.narrative: Centralized data management and systems maintenance leads to efficiency gains

baseline.value: Approx. EUR 0.15 million annual spending on duplicated maintenance, plus some EUR 0.4 million in duplicated equipment anddevelopment of stand-alone systems

target.value: Cost savings from ICT systems maintenance of 30% (compared to stand-alone systems)

actual.value: Fully met. The Data Center (DC) is fully operational and provides higher than expected savings. From the time that DC becameoperational in February 2014, most of government institutions have started to use DC infrastructure for their IT systems (Softwareapplications) that they previously hosted outside, including maintenance services.The largest savings to-date are coming from thehardware, because now some of institutions do not spending anymore on core hardware. for example, the Ministry of Health (MoH) isintroducing the Health Information System (HIS) and have agreed with MPA to host HIS using DC infrastructure, servers, storage,core networking equipment, maintenance services, etc. Therefore, the MoH avoided investments in centralized equipment andinfrastructure (new server room, core networking, storage, etc.) for HIS.

title.narrative: Improved quality of budget and MTEF submissions of beneficiary budget organizations

baseline.value: Beneficiary BOs comply with 3 out 7 budget submission quality criteria (see comment for explanation)

target.value: All 5 beneficiary BOs meet the 7 quality criteria

actual.value: Partially met- performance differs across beneficiaries.

title.narrative: HRMIS functions as a civil service registry and online data links between HRMIS-payroll-Treasury systems enable effective fiscal and management controls in payroll administration

baseline.value: HRMIS does not include grade or salary step data; includes only personnel data for 3 civil service organizations

target.value: HRMIS rolled out in all civil service organizations

actual.value: Partially met.HRMIS is rolled out in all government institutions, but it still has limited functionalities/modules.Majority ofpersonnel offices in the central and local government institutions use the HRMIS for recruitment and leave management. Accordingto data provided from MPA, starting from January 1, 2015 till June 30, 2016, about 900 recruitments of Civil Servants were preparedand announced through HRMIS. After adoption of the Job Classification by the Government (May 25, 2016), the MPA has startedentering data for each government institution in order to be ready to start with new job classification by September 1st, 2016.The new Civil Service regulations were adopted in early 2016 resulting in updates in HRMIS and addition of three modules: HRplanning module, module for recruitment of high level of civil servants and module for online application for government jobpositions in civil service (all work was supported by the PSMP).

title.narrative: Ministry responsible for public administration has necessary capacity to exercise key human resource management functions for the core civil service

baseline.value: MPA Department of Civil Service Administration has 25 staff (14 in payroll unit)

target.value: Department responsible for civil service management has staff trained in all core HR functions

actual.value: Met.The Department for Civil Service Administration (DCSA) within MPA increased its capacities through trainings. DCSA personnelis trained jointly with HR managers in suing the HRMIS modules and HRM functions ( usage of the new methodology for jobclassification, performance appraisal system, HR planning, etc.) and have become trainer for HRMIS and HR functions. The DCSAthrough their trainers regularly trains and provides support for personnel officers from all government institutions in the HRMISand HR functions. Separate training sessions were conducted for about 200 HR managers and HR officers in: HRMIS, Job Catalogueand Performance Appraisal Systems.

title.narrative: Enhanced security and interoperability of government information systems (through centralized data storage and systems maintenance,and interoperability framework)

baseline.value: No adequate, secure data storage and backup facility for major ICT systems;No interoperability between major ICT systems

target.value: Data center is operational;Reduced risk of data loss;Improved access to data control and physical security;New systems developedaccording to the interoperability framework.

actual.value: Fully met. The National Data Center was inaugurated in February 2014 and is fully operational.In addition, the ICT SecurityManagement Framework for Kosovo Government ICT Systems is developed and adopted by the MPA.

title.narrative: Status of public procurement activities is regularly monitored through contract management information system

baseline.value: No central capacity exists to monitor procurement cycle

target.value: PPA and PPRC use electronic system to regularly monitor public procurement activities by all contracting authorities in Kosovo

actual.value: Partially met.. Contract Management Information System (CMIS) is part of the E-procurement system modules. CMIS developed andtested by PPRC and verified that it is operational and provides functionalities for PPRC, CPA and each Contracting Authority tomanage and monitor contracts from the date of signing till contract completion. Starting from July 1st, 2016, CPA, PPRC and CAsincluded in piloting phase are in able to use the CMIS module for contract management and monitoring.

title.narrative: Transparent and coherent pay and grading structure introduced in the core civil service supported by improved ICT systems that enable effective fiscal and management controls in payroll administration

baseline.value: No grading system in the civil service; Wide pay variations among civil service bodies;PEFA indicator PI-18 (effectiveness ofpayroll controls) score: D+;No link between HRMIS, payroll, and Treasury

target.value: 100% of permanent civil servants graded; Equal bases pay for posts of equal grade and salary step across civil servicebodies;Improved PEFA PI-18 score (C+ or above)

actual.value: Partially met. On May 25, 2016 the Government of Kosovo has approved Job Classification (1500 Job titles and grading for 14500 of17000 civil servants) and obliged all government institutions to start implementation of new job classification from September 1,2016. This decision also requests the joint MoF/MPA commission to complete job classification of remaining 2500 of civil servantsby June 30 and propose value of the salary coefficients be used for in the new job classification and new payment structure. Asof June 30, the joint commission has not received any proposal on job classification from remaining institutions which means thatremaining jobs will classified automatically according to the job classification methodology. The value of the coefficient to beused for the new job classification and new payment structure are not proposed yet. Is likely that due to financial constraintsthe Government will start implementation of job classification as scheduled, but wi

title.narrative: Performance appraisal system is introduced and used as a basis for progression along salary steps

baseline.value: No regular performance appraisal system or mechanism for salary progression

target.value: Managers trained (no.); Performance appraisal launched in pilot organizations

actual.value: Partially met.The new guideline for implementation of the new performance appraisal system is developed and adopted by theMinister of MPA. About 200 HR managers and HR officers are trained to use the new performance appraisal system, which is aseparate module of the HRMIS. Civil service organizations are still not using this system as a mechanism for salary management.
